term_definitions.items: To record details of a laboratory specimen.
Unique identifier of the specimen, normally assigned by the laboratory.
Unique identifier of the parent specimen, where the specimen is split into sub-samples.
Any risk or biohazard associated with collecting or handling the specimen.
The method of collection to be used eg Venepuncture, biopsy, resection.
Any conditions to be met before the sample should be taken.

e.g. fasting, 'full bladder', 'sterile field' or any special instructions on the handling or immediate processing of the sample e.g. centrifuge on receipt.
Can also be used to document any known deviations from collection or handling instructions e.g patient was not fasted.
The anatomical site(s) from where the specimen was taken.
The date and time that collection has been ordered to take place or has taken place.
Dimensions / weight / quantity of sample or other physical details of a bodily fluid. Set as unbounded to allow variations e.g Weight of prostatic gland with and without seminal vesicles.
The type of specimen to be collected e.g venous blood, prostatic biopsy.
The date and time that the sample was received at the laboratory.
Is the specimen adequate for testing?
Specific issue with a received specimen.
Issue arising with handling or processing of the specimen within the laboratory.
An additional text comment on the quality of the received specimen.
An incorrect preservative was used when transporting the specimen.
An insufficient sample was given to undertake measurement.
An error arose when handling the specimen.
The specimen was too old to analyse accurately.
An accident occurred with the sample in the laboratory.
The specimen could not be analysed for technical reasons.
The specimen is of sufficient quality to allow reporting.
The specimen is unsatisfactory but has been processed.
The specimen is unsatisfactory and has not been processed.

Identification of the setting at which the specimen was collected from a subject of care. The specimen is often collected by a healthcare provider, but may be collected directly by the patient or carer at home.

This specifies the specimen collection location within the healthcare environment. It enables the laboratory to ask questions about the collection of the specimen, if required. The specimen collection setting may provide additional information relevant to the analysis of the result.
The specimen preparation cluster allows detailed recording of a particular preparation step e.g staining or fixation.
Identifier of the person or agency responsible for collecting the specimen.
The person or organisation responsible for collecting the specimen.
Additional detailed description of method of sample collection.
The total number of containers holding this specimen.
Addtional details related to specific collection methods e.g. needle biopsy.
The result of a laboratory test for a single analyte value.
For example: 'Sodium', 'White cell count', 'T3'. Commonly coded with an external terminology,

Actual value of the analyte result. The name of this element is normally replaced in a specialisation, in a template or at run-time to reflect the actual analyte e.g. Serum sodium and will often be coded.
Additional advice on the applicability of the reference range to this result or may carry text or coded textual guidance as to whether the result is within the normal range.
The status of the result value.
The date and/or time that the entire result was issued for the recorded ‘Analyte result status’.
Further detail regarding an individual result.
The existence of the test is registered in the Laboratory Information System, but there is nothing yet available.
This is a partial (e.g. initial, interim or preliminary) Test Result: data in the Test Result may be incomplete or unverified.
Verified early results are available, but not all results are final. This is a sub-category of 'Partial'.
The Test result is complete and verified by an authorised person.
The result has been modified subsequent to being Final, and is complete and verified by the responsible pathologist.
The result has been modified subsequent to being Final, and is complete and verified by the responsible pathologist, and result data has been changed. This is a sub-category of 'Corrected'.
Subsequent to being final, the report has been modified by adding new content. The existing content is unchanged. This is a sub-category of 'Corrected'.
The Test Result has been withdrawn following previous Final release.
The result is unavailable because the test was not started or not completed (also sometimes called 'aborted').
Further details including the individual analytes, specimen for the panel or a further nested panel.
Laboratory test result as a panel/battery/profile structure common to clinical pathology testing.
The result, including findings and interpretation of a laboratory investigation performed on patient-related specimens.
Default, unspecified point in time or interval event which may be explicitly defined in a template or at run-time.
Identification of the laboratory investigation performed by name.

A test result may be for a single analyte, or a group of items, including panel tests. May be coded terminologies for example, LOINC or SNOMED CT. Examples include 'Glucose', 'Urea and Electrolytes', 'Swab', “Cortisol (am)” or "Liver Biopsy". The name may sometimes include specimen type and patient state, for example "Fasting blood glucose"
Details of the laboratory which received, and has responsibility for managing the test request.
The receiving laboratory may either perform the test or refer it to another laboratory.
Details of additional clinicians or organisations who require a copy of the test result.
This is a partial (e.g. initial, interim or preliminary) Test Result: data in the Test Result may be incomplete or unverified.
The Test result is complete and verified by an authorised person.
The result has been modified subsequent to being Final, and is complete and verified by the responsible pathologist, and result data has been changed. This is a sub-category of 'Corrected'.
Narrative description of the key findings.
For example: 'Pattern suggests significant renal impairment'.
The local identifier assigned by the requesting clinical system.
Equivalent to the HL7 Placer Order Identifier.
The local identifier assigned to the test order by the order filler, usually by the Laboratory Information System (LIS).

Assigning an identifier to a request by the Laboratory lnformation System (LIS) enables tracking progress of the request and enables linking results to requests. It also provides a reference to assist with enquiries and it is usually equivalent to the HL7 Filler Order Identifier.
Details about the specimen, in the situation where all results in this test are derived from the same specimen.
If the specimen type is sufficiently specified with a code in the Test name, then this additional data is not required. If there are multiple specimens, these may be represented per 'Result group'.
The local identifier assigned by the receiving Laboratory Information System.
The status of the laboratory test result as a whole.
The result is unavailable because the test was not started or not completed (also sometimes called 'aborted').
The date and/or time that the entire result was issued for the recorded ‘Test status’.
The diagnostic service that performs the examination.

For example, biochemistry, haematology. This data elements assists filtering of broad categories of results according to local laboratory arrangements. Coding with a terminology is desirable, where possible.
Details of the clinician or organisation requesting the laboratory test result.

In most situations there is one test request and a single corresponding test result, however this repeating cluster allows for the situation where there may be multiple test requests reported using a single test result.
This slot may carry an individual analyte, a group, panel or battery of multiple results, or a more complex and specific structure.
Single word, phrase or brief description that represents the clinical meaning and significance of the laboratory test results.
For example: 'Severe hepatic impairment'. Coding of the diagnosis with a terminology is preferred, where possible.This diagnosis should be aligned with the narrative in the 'Conclusion'.
Description of clinical information available at the time of interpretation of results.
This data element may include a link to the original clinical information provided in the test request.
Additional narrative about the test result not captured in other fields.
Name of the original laboratory test requested, where the test requested differs from the test actually performed.
The existence of the test is registered in the Laboratory Information System, but there is nothing yet available.
Structured details about the laboratory test methodology used.
For example, structured details about the laboratory method and data interpretation used.
True if a point-of-care device supplies the test result rather than a formal laboratory service.
Issues or circumstances that impact on the accurate interpretation of the measurement or test result.
Details of issues or circumstances that impact on the accurate interpretation of the measurement or test result.
The result has been modified subsequent to being Final, and is complete and verified by the responsible pathologist.
The Test Result has been withdrawn following previous Final release.
Additional information required to capture local content or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
Digital image, video or diagram representing the test result.
Multiple formats are allowed but they should represent equivalent clinical content.
Subsequent to being final, the report has been modified by adding new content. The existing content is unchanged. This is a sub-category of 'Corrected'.
Verified early results are available, but not all results are final. This is a sub-category of 'Partial'.
Document to communicate information to others, commonly in response to a request from another party.
Document to communicate information to others about the result of a test or assessment.
The status of the entire report. Note: This is not the status of any of the report components.
Additional information required to capture local context or to align with other reference models/formalisms.
For example: local information requirements or additional metadata to align with FHIR or CIMI equivalents.
